key_facts: inZOI is a life simulation game developed as a potential competitor to The Sims.
The game was co-written with Eric and played on PC using a review copy.
inZOI features controllable characters called Zois, an open world, and drivable cars.
The character creator in inZOI allows for detailed customization of appearance and clothing.
AI-generated textures can be created via text prompts within the game's interface.
The game includes a 3D printer feature that converts 2D images into 3D objects.
Players can import YouTube videos to play on city billboards in real time.
City management tools allow players to adjust cleanliness levels and weather conditions.
Players can build structures anywhere on the map, including on sidewalks or public streets.
The game supports facial mapping for avatar animation, though it is currently non-functional.
Motion capture support is present but requires external hardware and has no practical use yet.
Emote generation lets users convert images or video into animations, but results are poor.
Zois can become ghosts after death, but the ghost mode feature is not yet implemented.
Driving mechanics in inZOI are poorly implemented with unrealistic physics and controls.
Cars can randomly teleport the player to a hidden space beneath the world map.
Characters may exhibit pathfinding bugs, walking through walls or getting stuck indefinitely.
The game crashes frequently, with reports of crashes every 20 minutes or less.
inZOI runs in early access and lacks core gameplay depth and meaningful life goals.
The visual style blends corporate training video aesthetics with surreal, uncanny elements.
The framing story involves magic cats who govern the creation and lives of Zois.
Cats serve as tutorial guides, grant boons, and rule the underworld in-game.
The game’s lighting system causes AI-generated textures to appear garbled or blown out.
Custom clothing options include adjustable collars, sleeves, and materials.
The game offers two distinct character types: uncanny supermodels and Yakuza-level freaks.
The game’s initial state is set to 100% cleanliness, which can be altered to create post-apocalyptic environments.
key_opinions: inZOI feels like a breath of fresh air compared to the stagnant evolution of The Sims series.
The game’s ambition is admirable, even if its execution is cursed and chaotic.
The juxtaposition between clean corporate presentation and bizarre features creates a unique tone.
While derivative, the game is still better than nothing given the lack of competition in the genre.
The current state of the game is extremely rough and not ready for most players.
Many features feel pointless or barely functional, but they contribute to the game’s strangeness.
The game’s charm lies in its experimental nature and willingness to embrace absurdity.
The developers should have delayed release to fix critical bugs before launch.
The potential for inZOI to evolve into a strong competitor to The Sims is real.
Players seeking deep gameplay will be disappointed by the thin core mechanics.
The game rewards experimentation more than traditional playthroughs.
The driving mechanic is so broken it undermines any sense of realism or fun.
The ghost resurrection feature being absent despite being advertised is misleading.
The inclusion of AI texture generation is technically interesting but practically useless.
The ability to turn buildings into mirrors or LED screens adds to the surreal aesthetic.
The game’s weirdness is not a flaw—it’s part of its identity and appeal.
The developers likely received significant funding, suggesting long-term commitment is possible.
The game’s current form is more a collection of features than a cohesive product.
Despite flaws, there’s genuine excitement about what inZOI could become.
The game’s early access status justifies some tolerance, but not endless instability.
